tn.text: The writer Luke, Paul, and his companions continue their travels.
Here the word "we" refers to the writer Luke, Paul, and those traveling with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])

tn.ref: we took a straight course to the city of Cos
tn.text: "we went straight to the city of Cos" or "we went directly to the city of Cos"
Cos is a Greek island off the coast of modern day Turkey in the South Aegean Sea region. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Rhodes is a Greek island off the coast of modern day Turkey in the South Aegean Sea region south of Cos and northeast of Crete. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Patara is a city on the southwest coast of modern day Turkey south of the Aegean Sea in the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: When we found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia
tn.text: Here "a ship crossing over" stands for the crew that would sail the ship. AT: "When we found a ship with a crew sailing over to Phoenicia" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "crossing" does not mean it was presently crossing but that it would be crossing to Phoenicia soon. AT: "a ship that would be going across the water" or "a ship that would be going"
Here the word "we" refers to Luke, Paul, and those traveling with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"passed the island on the left"

tn.ref: that the ship was to unload its cargo
tn.text: Here "ship" stands for the crew that was sailing the ship. AT: "the crew would unload the cargo from the ship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: These disciples said to Paul through the Spirit
tn.text: "These believers told Paul what the Holy Spirit had revealed to them"

tn.ref: that he should not set foot in Jerusalem
tn.text: Here "foot" stands for the whole person. AT: "that he should not go to Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "They" refers to the believers from Tyre.

tn.ref: When we had spent the days
tn.text: This speaks about days as if they were something that a person could spend. AT: "When the seven days were over" or "When it was time to leave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: knelt down on the beach, prayed
tn.text: It was a common custom to kneel down while praying. This was a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"said goodbye to one another"
This begins Paul's time in Caesarea.
Here the word "we" refers to Luke, Paul and those traveling with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
Ptolemaic was a city south of Tyre, Lebanon. Ptolemaic is modern day Acre, Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"fellow believers"
The "seven" refers to the men chosen to distribute food and aid to the widows in [[:en:bible:notes:act:06:05|6:5]].
"Philip" from verse 8.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke tells background information about Philip and his daughters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"four virgin daughters who regularly received and passed along messages from God"
This tells about a prophecy made about Paul in Caesarea by the prophet Agabus.
Here the words "we" and "us" refers to Luke, Paul, and those with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
This introduces a new person in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Agabus was a man from Judea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"removed Paul's belt from Paul's waist"

tn.ref: Thus says the Holy Spirit, 'So shall the Jews in Jerusalem tie up ... of the Gentiles.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. The inner quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "'The Holy Spirit says that this will be how the Jews in Jerusalem will tie up ... of the Gentiles.' (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This does not mean all the Jews, but that these were the people who would do that. AT: "the Jewish leaders" or "some of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"deliver him"

tn.ref: into the hands of the Gentiles
tn.text: The word "hands" here represents control. AT: "into the legal custody of the Gentiles" or "to the Gentiles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
This stands for the authorities among the Gentiles. AT: "the Gentile authorities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "we" refers to Luke and the other believers but does not include Paul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart
tn.text: Paul asks this question to show the believers they should stop trying to persuade him. AT: "Stop what you are doing. Your weeping is breaking my heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])

To make someone sad or to discourage someone is spoken of as if it were a heart being broken. Here "heart" stands for a person's emotions. AT: "discouraging me" or "making me very sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: not only to be tied up
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "not only for them to tie me up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: for the name of the Lord Jesus
tn.text: Here "name" refers to the person of Jesus. AT: "for the sake of the Lord Jesus" or "because I believe in the Lord Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: did not wish to be persuaded
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "did not want us to try to persuade him not to go to Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: May the will of the Lord be done
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May everything happen as the Lord has planned it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This ends Paul's time in Caesarea.
Here the word "we" refers to Luke, Paul and those traveling with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
The word "They" refers to some of the disciples from Caesarea.

tn.ref: They brought with them a man
tn.text: "Among them was a man"
Mnason is a man from the island of Cyprus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
This means Mnason was one of the first to believe in Jesus.
Paul and his companions arrive in Jerusalem.
Here the words "he" and "his" refers to Paul. The word "them" refers to the elders.
Here "brothers" refers to the believers in Jerusalem whether male or female. AT: "the fellow believers welcomed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
"he gave a detailed account of all"
The elders in Jerusalem begin their response to Paul.
Here the word "they" refers to James and the elders.
The word "him" refers to Paul.
The word "They" refers to Jewish believers who wanted all believing Jews to keep the Jewish laws and customs.
The words "them" and "their" refers to Jewish people who believe in Christ.
Here "brother" means "fellow believer."

tn.ref: They have been told about you ... not to follow the old customs
tn.text: Apparently here there are some Jews that are distorting what Paul is teaching. He does not discourage the Jews from obeying the Law of Moses. His message is that circumcision and the other customs are not necessary for Jesus to save them. You can make explicit that the leaders of the Jewish believers in Jerusalem knew that Paul was teaching God's true message. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People have told the Jewish believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
Here "Moses" stands for the law of Moses. AT: "to stop obeying the laws that Moses gave us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: not to follow the old customs
tn.text: To obey the old customs is spoken of as if the customs were leading them and the people follow behind. AT: "not to obey the old customs" or "not to practice the old customs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the customs that Jews normally do"
Here the word "we" refers to James and the elders. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:17|21:18]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
The word "They" refers to the Jewish believers in Jerusalem who wanted to teach Jewish believers that they could still follow the laws of Moses. (See:  [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:20|21:20-21]]

The words "them," "their," and the first "they" refer to the four men who made a vow. The second words "they" and "They" refer to the Jewish believers in Jerusalem who wanted to teach Jewish believers that they could still follow the laws of Moses.

tn.ref: four men who made a vow
tn.text: "four men who made a promise to God." This was the kind of vow where a person would not drink alcohol or cut his hair until the end of a set period of time.

tn.ref: Take these men and purify yourself with them
tn.text: They had to make themselves ritually pure so they could worship in the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"pay for what they will need." The expenses would go toward buying a male and female lamb, a ram, and grain and drink offerings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This was a sign that the person had completed what they promised God they would do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: the things they have been told about you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the things that people are saying about you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This speaks of obeying the law as if the law were a leader and the people follow behind it. AT: "obey the law" or "live a life that conforms to the law of Moses and other Jewish customs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
James and the elders in Jerusalem finish their request to Paul. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:17|21:18]])
Here the word "we" refers to James and the elders. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])

tn.ref: they should keep themselves from things sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what is strangled
tn.text: All of these are rules about what they can eat. They are forbidden to eat meat of animals sacrificed to an idol, meat with blood still in it, and meat from a strangled animal because it would still have blood in the meat. See how you translated similar phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:act:15:19|15:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they should keep themselves from things sacrificed to idols
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they stay away from the meat of an animal that someone sacrificed to an idol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This can be stated in active form. You can also state explicitly the assumed information about strangled animals. AT: "from animals that a person has strangled" or "from animals that a person killed for food but did not drain its blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These are the 4 men who made a vow.
Before entering the temple area the Jews were required to be ceremonially or ritually clean. This cleansing had to do with Jews having contact with Gentiles.

They did not go into the temple itself where only the high priest was allowed to enter. They entered the temple courtyard. AT: "went into the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a separate purification process from the purification process which they were required to fulfill in order to enter the temple area.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "until they presented the animals for an offering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This begins the story of Paul's arrest.
Verse 29 gives background information about the Jews from Asia.
These are the seven days for purification.
Paul was not in the temple itself. He was in the temple courtyard. AT: "in the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"caused a large number of people to start a protest"
Here "laid hands on" means to "seize" or to "grab." See how you translated "laid hands on" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:17|5:18]]. AT: "grabbed Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the people, the law, and this place
tn.text: "the people of Israel, the law of Moses, and the temple"

tn.ref: Besides, he has also brought Greeks into the temple
tn.text: Only Jewish males were allowed in certain areas of the courtyard of the Jerusalem temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: For they had previously ... into the temple
tn.text: This is background information. Luke is explaining why the Jews from Asia thought Paul brought a Greek into the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This was a Greek man that they accused Paul of having brought into the inner temple area that was only for Jews. See how you translated his name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:04|20:4]].

The word "All" here is an exaggeration for emphasis. The word "city" represents the people in Jerusalem. AT: "Many people in the city became angry at Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
"seized Paul" or "grabbed Paul"

They shut the doors so that there would not be rioting in the temple area. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Some of the Jews immediately shut the temple doors" or "The temple guards immediately shut the doors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: news came up to the chief captain of the guard
tn.text: Here "news" refers to the messenger who went to speak the news. AT: "someone gave news to the chief captain of the guard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: news came up to the chief captain
tn.text: The phrase "came up to" is used because the chief captain was in a fortress connected to the temple that was higher in elevation than the temple courtyard.
a Roman military officer or leader of about 600 soldiers

tn.ref: all Jerusalem was in an uproar
tn.text: The word "Jerusalem" here represents the people of Jerusalem. The word "all" is an exaggeration to show a large crowd was upset. AT: "a lot of people in Jerusalem were in an uproar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
The first word  "he" and the word "He" refer to the chief captain of the guard mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:30|21:31]].
From the fortress, there are stairs going down into the court.
a Roman military officer or leader of about 600 soldiers
"took hold of Paul" or "arrested Paul"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "commanded his soldiers to bind him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means they bound Paul to two Roman soldiers, one on each side of him.

tn.ref: He asked who he was and what he had done
tn.text: This can be stated as a direct quotation. AT: "He asked, "Who is this man? What has he done?'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The chief captain is speaking to the crowd, not to Paul.
This was a military officer or leader of about 600 soldiers.

tn.ref: he ordered that Paul be brought
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he ordered his soldiers to bring Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This fortress was connected to the outer temple court.

tn.ref: When he came to the steps, he was carried
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "When Paul came to the steps of the fortress, the soldiers carried him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The crowd is using somewhat milder and less exact language to ask for Paul's death. AT: "Put him to death" or "Kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: As Paul was about to be brought
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "As the soldiers were ready to bring Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This fortress was connected to the outer temple court. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:21:34|21:34]].
a Roman military officer of about 600 soldiers

tn.ref: Do you speak Greek? Are you not then the Egyptian, who previously led a rebellion and took the four thousand terrorists into the wilderness?
tn.text: The chief captain uses these questions to express surprise that Paul is not who he thought he was. AT: "So you speak Greek. I thought you were that Egyptian who led a rebellion in the wilderness with the four thousand terrorists" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: Are you not then the Egyptian
tn.text: Shortly before Paul's visit, an unnamed man from Egypt had launched a revolt against Rome in Jerusalem. Later he escaped "into the desert," and the commander wonders if Paul might be the same man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This word "rebellion" can be stated as a verb. AT: "caused people to rebel against the Roman government" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"the 4,000 terrorists" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"assassins." Here this refers to Jews who killed Romans and anyone who supported Romans.
Paul begins to defend what he did.
"I beg you" or "I plead with you"
"please allow me" or please permit me"

tn.ref: the captain had given him permission
tn.text: The word "permission" can be stated as a verb. AT: "the captain permitted Paul to speak" or "the captain allowed Paul to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "steps" here refers to the steps on the stairway to the fortress.

tn.ref: motioned with the hand to the people
tn.text: It can be stated explicitly why Paul motioned with the hand. AT: "motioned with his hand for the people to be quiet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: When there was a deep silence
tn.text: "When the people were completely silent"
